DR. REED'S GREAT WORK.
-----
Wash. Post
1/20/03
div1.p:
Substantial Expression of Government
Appreciation to His Widow Hoped For.

Editor Post: America has a long line of
eminent physicians and surgeons to her
credit, and not a few who have been lead-
ers in scientific investigation, but it has
never yet fallen to the good fortune of
any one man to do as much for his fel-
low-countrymen as the late Walter Reed.

Through Dr. Reed's efforts, carried on
at great risk to his life and with the act-
ual loss of one precious life, the plague
of yellow fever, which has devastated this
country for centuries, has been eliminat-
ed. Had Dr. Reed discovered some rem-
edy, which, injected into the veins of a
victim of the fever, would save a consid-
erable percentage of lives, he would un-
doubtedly have been reckoned a great dis-
coverer and have received decorations and
medals and awards.

How fortunate it is that his actual dis-
covery was vastly more than this--de-
tecting the cause of the disease and de-
termining that it was of such a nature
that henceforth no one need contract the
fever who does not actually want it.

He has saved our country countless
thousands of lives, millions of dollars,
and brought lasting credit upon the en-
tire medical profession in wiping out one
of the greatest scourges of humanity.

It is for these reasons that the entire
profession of North America looks to
Washington, confidently expecting that
our government will find in his early
death an opportunity of expressing its
appreciation to his wife in a most sub-
stantial form.

HOWARD A. KELLY, M. D.,
Professor Gynecological Surgery, Johns
Hopkins University.
